This has become a widely shared post....and it deserves to be. What educators in Wolcott and everywhere around this nation have achieved in a short time, with little warning, and with no precedent is astounding, inspiring, and just plain awesome!

As I see and hear about the ways in which our staff is serving the children of Wolcott, it warms my heart and gives me hope. When I realize the ways in which parents and the community have partnered with us in this work it amazes me.

Have a restful weekend,
Tony Gasper
Superintendent of Schools
shared_text:
Ken Buck
March 18 at 9:47 AM ·

We gave educators almost no notice. We asked them to completely redesign what school looks like and in about 24 hours local administrators and teachers "Apollo 13'ed" the problem and fixed it. Kids learning, children being fed, needs being met in the midst of a global crisis.
No state agency did this, no so-called national experts on curriculum. The local educators fixed it in hours. HOURS.
In fact, existing state and federal policies actually created multiple roadblocks. Local schools figured out how to do it around those too. No complaining and no handwringing - just solutions and amazingly clever plans.
Remember that the next time someone tries to convince you that schools are better run by mandates from non-educators. Remember that the next time someone tells you that teachers have it easy or try to persuade you that educators are not among the smartest, most ingenious people in society. And please never say to me again, "Those who can't do anything else just go into teaching."
Get out of the way of a teacher and watch with amazement at what really happens.

With talk of the Corona Virus flooding the press, it's important to remember that the annual flu is a MUCH greater health concern as evidenced by national statistics. The Centers for Disease Control provide excellent guidance for all of us in trying to prevent the flu:
* Wash and/or sanitize your hands frequently.
* If your child is sick, please keep them home.
* Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze. After using a tissue, throw it in the trash and wash your hands.
* Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth.

A team of Wolcott students, parents, teachers and administrators has begun the process of seeking NEASC accreditation for all five of our schools. While WHS and most high schools in New England are already accredited, district-wide accreditation is a fairly new concept.

Though we have much to celebrate as a school district, we will not rest on our past successes. Accreditation is a way to ensure that we are constantly challenging ourselves to be better by measuring our schools against rigorous standards set out by NEASC. We will use the accreditation process to ensure that students in grades K-12 experience a meaningful and connected educational journey.

Thank you to the 14 students, parents, and staff members who have volunteered their time to meet after school to complete our application for candidacy.

https://cps.neasc.org/district-accreditation
